original_theorem: If $X_1, X_2, X_3$ are independent exponential random variables with parameters $\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \lambda_3$, respectively, then $P(X_1 < \min(X_2, X_3)) = \frac{\lambda_1}{\lambda_1 + \lambda_2 + \lambda_3}$.
theorem_translation:
```lean4
theorem competition_of_exponentials
    -- Let Ω be a probability space.
    {Ω : Type*} [MeasureSpace Ω]
    {P : Measure Ω} [IsProbabilityMeasure P]
    -- Let r₁, r₂, r₃ be the rates of the exponential distributions.
    {r₁ r₂ r₃ : ℝ}
    -- Let X₁, X₂, X₃ be three real-valued random variables.
    {X₁ X₂ X₃ : Ω → ℝ}
    -- Assume they follow exponential distributions with the given rates.
    -- This implies the rates are positive.
    (hX₁_exp : ProbabilityTheory.IsExponential X₁ r₁ P)
    (hX₂_exp : ProbabilityTheory.IsExponential X₂ r₂ P)
    (hX₃_exp : ProbabilityTheory.IsExponential X₃ r₃ P)
    -- Assume the random variables are mutually independent.
    -- This implies they are measurable.
    (hindep : ProbabilityTheory.iIndepFun (fun (_ : Fin 3) ↦ borel ℝ) ![X₁, X₂, X₃] P) :
    -- Then the probability that X₁ is the minimum of the three is given by this formula.
    P {ω | X₁ ω < min (X₂ ω) (X₃ ω)} = r₁ / (r₁ + r₂ + r₃) := by
```

    -- Let Ω be a probability space.
    {Ω : Type*} [MeasureSpace Ω]

    -- Let r₁, r₂, r₃ be the rates of the exponential distributions.
    {r₁ r₂ r₃ : ℝ}

    {X₁ X₂ X₃ : Ω → ℝ}
